As lata as 19U2 some educators thought it to be a self-evident fact that any
"good” program or any worthwhile subject matter would of necessity attract a
small audience. The fact that this was often merely a rationalization for bad
performance escaped these would-be analysts.
Radio broadcasting in the United States before World War* II developed 900
stations, but educational radio had failed to enjoy a proportionate growth.
There were only 30 odd AM stations. While much was written and spoken about
the problems and the opportunities, many gatherings were held, and many in¬
stitutions in one way or another participated, the inescapable fact was
that educational radio was not a vital factor in United States life, although
almost everywhere one could get admissions that it should be.
In some instances smart and ruthless commercial operators skillfully stripped
the radio facilities away from Institutions which did not value or could not
hold them. Columbia University, for instance, at one time refused as a gift
what is now the NBC key radio station in New York. The University of New
Mexico was gradually infiltrated and finally lost its facilities to an adroit
commercial operator. Iowa State College similarly approached in an early day
placed a value of a million dollars on the radio facility and scared off such
intruders.
In the U0*s a renaissance in educational broadcasting began to take place, be¬
ginning with the work of Harold A. Engel of the University of Wisconsin who
set a goal of- 100 institutional members for NAEB during his term as president.
He had been active in the move to reserve FM channels for education when FM
was thought to be a "whit© hope” for United States radio 0 Hull of Iowa State
College, Siegel, Communications Director of New York City, and Qraydon Ausmus
of the University of Alabama inherited his successful work as the succeeding
presidents and carried on the same aims. NAEB began to get an organization
of national scope instead of a "social club” of station managers. (Just be¬
fore the war a national meeting of NAEB members brought 9 people from the
entire country. Now such meetings bring 200 or more representatives and people.
At the Rockefeller Seminar at the University of Illinois severs! years ago the
basis for most of the development leading up to the present situation for the
NAEB and educational television was established.
CEt should be noted that the renaissance of the NAEB was a major factor in lead¬
ing Wilbur Schramm, Dean of Communications at the University of Illinois,
Morris A. Novik, New York radio consultant, and others to consider and seek
financing for such a seminar, e. g. much had happened to substantiate the idea
of holding a seminar.)
From that meeting came some remarkably basic conclusions and predictions about
the future of educational radio and television in answer to the basic seminar
question—"Where, if anywhere, is educational radio going?”.
